All these resources are (a) copied to the build version, enlarging the deploy package, and (b) their resource infos blow up the application script.
The reason is the wild card include of all those resources by gratuitous #asset hints in the theme:
qx.theme.modern.Decoration: ... #asset(qx/decoration/Modern/*)
A possible cure would be to move the #asset hints from the theme to the corresponding widgets. This way, each widget would bring in just the resources it needs, and only those would be generated into the app. E.g.
qx.ui.groupbox.GroupBox.js: ... #asset(qx/decoration/{qx.theme}/groupbox/*)

Sounds like a problem not easy to fix because moving the assets into the widget code breaks the idea of the theming and of "not knowing" anything about the theme in the widget code. Maybe we have to split up the theme? That would help but could be hard.
--> Thomas

Good idea of a more tailor-made resource handling for theming. But the explicit configuration within a widget's code won't work for the reasons Martin also mentioned.
Best we should probably do is taking advantage of the indirection introducted by the appearance id. By determining (or configuring) the resources per appearance id and "linking" the actually used ids for a certain app, we could get the desired result.
This linking of appearance ids is IMHO similar to the linking of static methods, so we could probably tackle this task, i.e. a link granularity below class level, maybe simultaneously. In a first step, this would mean using explicit exclude lists for appearance ids or static methods, respectively. Thomas, do you think that's feasible?

Actually, I don't quite get what both of you are saying.
-> Martin: The widget code does not have to know about which Theme is being used. Maybe you overlooked the use of {qx.theme} in "#asset(qx/decoration/{qx.theme}/groupbox/*)"?! But the widget code knows and has, IMO, to explicate which resources it needs. So the #asset hint belongs to the widget. This is also what we recommend for custom applications. But maybe we need a new way to encode which resources are used.
-> Andreas: How should this "linking of appearance ids" look like? What is the use case for having "a link granularity below class level"?

Quoting bug #7045 (which reports the same issue):
> This fixes the issue as far as icons are concerned. > Inside the build directory are still many probably unneeded decoration files. > I'm ignoring them for now, cause it's not clear how our Theming will evolve, > so it would be a waste of effort.
I leave this bug open as a reminder to revisit this issue (too many decoration imgs) after a Theming revamp.

The decoration images are still drawn into the build of the Desktop skeleton (400+ files), even after the changes that came with diet. Martin and Daniel are looking into that.
Taking this on 3.0.
Cleaned up the modern theme and removed the asset hint which included all decoration images for the modern theme: d49c5a92d28c017bcd662d1173f56f587dc92dba

Also cleaned up the appearance of the modern theme which included all decoration images as well: 4bccae5ef221e69aa2591639e97c1bf253a35bbb
The classic theme's appearance still has its include for all decoration images of the classic theme. But there are only 155 files in the skeletons resource build which seems not too much.

Despite the gains in the Modern theme we should try the same method for Classic.
Beyond that, shouldn't we consider a more general approach of avoiding unneeded image resources in app builds?! If you want the widgets to be "resource-agnostic", maybe we could split up e.g. the "Appearance" theme class in multiple classes, where each such class only hold the definitions - and @asset hints - for a *single* framework class. And then find a way to only include those that refer to classes that are actually used.
-> Martin
